clinical_particulars.therapeutic_indications: For use as adjunctive treatment with thiazide diuretics or other kaliuretic diuretic agents in congestive heart failure or hypertension

contraindications.disease: No data are available in regard to overdosage in humans The oral LD sub 50 sub of amiloride hydrochloride calculated as the base is 56 mg kg in mice and 36 to 85 mg kg in rats depending on the strain The most likely signs and symptoms to be expected with overdosage are dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
contraindications.pharmacodynamics: Amiloride an antikaliuretic diuretic agent is a pyrazine carbonyl guanidine that is unrelated chemically to other known antikaliuretic or diuretic agents It is an antihypertensive potassium sparing diuretic that was first approved for use in 1967 and helps to treat hypertension and congestive heart failure The drug is often used in conjunction with thiazide or loop diuretics Due to its potassium sparing capacities hyperkalemia high blood potassium levels are occasionally observed in patients taking amiloride The risk is high in concurrent use of ACE inhibitors or spironolactone Patients are also advised not to use potassium containing salt replacements
